articles.headline: Israel’s Hard-Liners Want to ‘Go Big’: Annex a Settlement
articles.snippet: Right-wing Israeli politicians emboldened by the Trump administration are eager to annex Ma’ale Adumim, but Palestinians say such a move would be the last straw.
articles.abstract: Right-wing Israeli politicians emboldened by the Trump administration are eager to annex Ma’ale Adumim, but Palestinians say such a move would be the last straw.
articles.lead_paragraph: MA’ALE ADUMIM, West Bank — The first babies of Ma’ale Adumim, a hilly city on the eastern outskirts of Jerusalem, are now middle-aged. A cemetery finally opened last year, and 40 residents are buried there, most dead of natural causes after long and peaceful lives.

articles.headline: Trump’s Trade War May Have Already Begun
articles.snippet: With Mr. Trump threatening punitive tariffs on Mexican and Chinese imports, some American allies are shifting focus to other potential alliances and sources of trade.
articles.abstract: With Mr. Trump threatening punitive tariffs on Mexican and Chinese imports, some American allies are shifting focus to other potential alliances and sources of trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — America’s traditional allies are on the lookout for new friends.

articles.headline: For Leaders of U.S. Allies, Getting Close to Trump Can Sting
articles.snippet: The leaders of Britain, Mexico, Japan, Canada and even Australia have been burned after what seemed like friendly interactions, causing political troubles.
articles.abstract: The leaders of Britain, Mexico, Japan, Canada and even Australia have been burned after what seemed like friendly interactions, causing political troubles.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — It had all been going so well.

articles.headline: Trump Fires Acting Attorney General Who Defied Him
articles.snippet: The acting attorney general, Sally Q. Yates, on Monday ordered government lawyers not to defend President Trump’s executive order on immigration in court.
articles.abstract: The acting attorney general, Sally Q. Yates, on Monday ordered government lawyers not to defend President Trump’s executive order on immigration in court.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump fired his acting attorney general on Monday night, removing her as the nation’s top law enforcement officer after she defiantly refused to defend his executive order closing the nation’s borders to refugees and people from predominantly Muslim countries.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Mark Landler, Matt Apuzzo and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Boy Scouts, Reversing Century-Old Stance, Will Allow Transgender Boys
articles.snippet: The Boy Scouts of America said that the group would begin accepting members based on the gender listed on their application.
articles.abstract: The Boy Scouts of America said that the group would begin accepting members based on the gender listed on their application.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reversing a stance of more than a century, the Boy Scouts of America said on Monday that the group would begin accepting members based on the gender listed on their application, paving the way for transgender boys to join the organization.

articles.headline: Frantic Phoning Among C.E.O.s: How to Address Trump Ban?
articles.snippet: Whispered questions among business leaders over the weekend produced no clear consensus on what to say about the President Trump’s immigration order in public.
articles.abstract: Whispered questions among business leaders over the weekend produced no clear consensus on what to say about the President Trump’s immigration order in public.
articles.lead_paragraph: The phone calls flew back and forth among the nation’s top chief executives over the weekend, all asking the same questions: “What are you going to say publicly about Trump’s executive order? And what can we say about it without becoming his next punching bag?”

articles.headline: In Ban on Migrants, Trump Supporters See a Promise Kept
articles.snippet: President Trump’s new immigration policy has support among a broad and deep swath of the electorate that is anxious about terrorism.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s new immigration policy has support among a broad and deep swath of the electorate that is anxious about terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sal Oliva, a hotel worker and Uber courier from Staten Island, is ecstatic about President Trump’s executive order. So are Michael Bower, an owner of a home alarm company in Seattle, and Lynn and Don Broesch, retirees from suburban Milwaukee.

articles.headline: Betsy DeVos Invests in a Therapy Under Scrutiny
articles.snippet: The nominee for education secretary is a chief investor in Neurocore, a group of brain performance centers whose methods have been questioned.
articles.abstract: The nominee for education secretary is a chief investor in Neurocore, a group of brain performance centers whose methods have been questioned.
articles.lead_paragraph: A group of brain performance centers backed by Betsy DeVos, the nominee for education secretary, promotes results that are nothing short of stunning: improvements reported by 91 percent of patients with depression, 90 percent with attention deficit disorder, 90 percent with anxiety.
articles.byline: By Sheri Fink, Steve Eder and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: State Dept. Officials Should Quit if They Disagree With Trump, White House Warns
articles.snippet: It was yet another stark confrontation between the new president and a federal bureaucracy struggling with the jolting change of power in Washington.
articles.abstract: It was yet another stark confrontation between the new president and a federal bureaucracy struggling with the jolting change of power in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Monday warned State Department officials that they should leave their jobs if they did not agree with President Trump’s agenda, an extraordinary effort to stamp out a wave of internal dissent against Mr. Trump’s temporary ban on entry visas for people from seven predominantly Muslim countries.

articles.headline: For Couriers, China’s E-Commerce Boom Can Be a Tough Road
articles.snippet: More than a million people are paid to zip through Chinese cities delivering packages, but their grueling work faces growing scrutiny from labor experts.
articles.abstract: More than a million people are paid to zip through Chinese cities delivering packages, but their grueling work faces growing scrutiny from labor experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Zhang Heng barged through an exam-room door, surprising a doctor and a patient. He didn’t have time to knock. In Mr. Zhang’s business, every second counts.

articles.headline: Trump and Trade: Extreme Tactics in Search of a Point
articles.snippet: Rejecting the premise of international accords is one thing. But displaying irrationality for effect, without a rational objective, can end in war.
articles.abstract: Rejecting the premise of international accords is one thing. But displaying irrationality for effect, without a rational objective, can end in war.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Mearsheimer, a noted political scientist at the University of Chicago, has long believed that China’s rise will not be peaceful. Tensions with the United States will simmer as the Asian giant expands its influence.
